doc.headline: Eddie Izzard as an MP/MEP?
doc.post:
I've heard a few times that Eddie Izzard one day will try and take up public office.
What are your thoughts on this?
I personally think he can achieve alot, having a great skill in reaching out to people.
Discuss

In the words of Mrs Thatcher "No, no, no!"

Originally Posted by Prudy We can only speculate but that may be more to do with his pro EU stance as opposed to an affinity with Labour, although he has donated money to the party. Still, he may become an independant.
hmmm yes independent would probably work.
However, everytime I read/listen to his aspirations and what he wants to do.. I reckon he'll end up in a group game.
anyways heres a link if anyone wants it
http://www.guardian.co.uk/culture/20...ty-marathon-mp
He seems very intelligent and open minded even in his stand up material. He's also had a very normal life before becoming succesfull in stand up and as such I think he'd be a good voice in politics.

What, is he going to offer us cake or death at the poll station?
I'm good with it.
He's also said he wants to do it within the next 10 to 15 years, so that's a long time for the political landscape to change and for his opinions to change.
I'd probably vote for him. Not just because I like his comedy, but I also agree with him on a lot of his political opinions.

Eddie Izzard, like Ricky Gervais, Peter Kay and so on, is a comedian.
Occasionally, those talented enough to entertain us can often deem themselves suitable for politics because RELATIVE to their field, they consider themselves to be intelligent.
Eddie Izzard is a smart chap, but he hasn't got the first clue about the body politic, and has dedicated his life to comedy. What divine intervention makes such people decide that after all these years of success in an industry like music, art, comedy, think they can then govern the country?
Izzard, like Gervais, Clarkson, etc would fail at being a politician because they have never invested the time to take it seriously. Only in mock.
Eddie Izzard has been somewhat active in politics for a while. Anyway, who says entertainers can't make good politicians? Look at the governer of California.

I don't think this is a good idea. If I was a Labour Party activist, gradually weaseling my way into the higher echelons of power over many years, only to find Eddie Izzard has nicked in ahead of me to be selected as a candidate for the European Parliament, well I'd be pretty pissed off. If Izzard is selected it would send out the wrong message to people who want to go into politics. Izzard may have donated some money here and there and showed up in a broadcast, but he's hardly dedicated himself to the cause.

If Eddie Izzard did go for public office I'd be worried that people were voting for him because he's a comedic legend than a person fit for helping govern the country. I'm skeptical if I'm honest. Its important people reason why MPs are there (yes I know its easy to forget) - to be an active part in parliament not to entertain us with witty remarks on Question Time. I like him though and if he came up with substance, I'd be in favour but only if he went through the official routes to power.
He can't decide whether he's a man or a woman, I don't want him making decisions that effect me. Why is being on telly a passport to everything? It's moronic.
